comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Great continuity in subject matter and shots Carol, this does illustrate the fact that the building was gutted in the fire.  That bell on the shot next door is really impressive, I'd say many a man and woman stood under that to dodge the rain on soft spring days?

comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: It's also pretty impressive that the facade remains intact. I wonder if it was supported by a steel girder... I'm not sure how often such building techniques would have been employed in provinical Irish cities in at the turn of the century

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Granville Hotel is still there, and now includes all of the burnt-out site.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I was wondering what a giant bell was doing outside a Chemist's, until I saw the sign down below the window!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The two hand-powered fire pumps are marked with the War Department broad arrow. They look similar to this Tilley fire engine. www.cambsfire.gov.uk/news/Archive/2103.php Two rows of men stood either side and worked the handles up and down like a seesaw.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Another great photo, Hearnes was a favourite of mine as a child, a virtual Alladdins cave. They had a system that used cables to take customers money up to a little office where a receipt and change were issued and then sent back down to the sales desk. Wire type Cash handling system Also Bells survived into the 60's I have very faint memories of it. Carte De Visite taken at Bells around 1900 I would guess

comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 94903955@N04
comment._content: Loved the pic of the interior of the shop..... I remember it well as a small child.  I was fascinated too by the money contraption in the "air".  Does anyone know when Hearne's shop closed down?  My father worked there for years but I can'remember when he left.
